p: Before we dismiss this second approach, however, there are three important points to emphasise. First, there are good reasons to include vaguer principles that allow for interpretation. Consider this in relation to risk, negligence and recklessness. It is simply not possible to predict every way in which it is possible for a person to act—for example—recklessly. If we relied only on the first type of principle, we would be very prone to wrong-doers finding loopholes, arguing—for example—that there was no law against driving while blind-folded.
